Award.AwardTitle: TC:Large:Collaborative Research:Anonymizing Textual Data and its Impact on Utility

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data Protection laws that exempt data that is not individually
identifiable have led to an explosion in anonymization research.
Unfortunately, how well current de-identification and anonymization
techniques control risks to privacy and confidentiality is not well
understood. Neither is the usefulness of anonymized data for real-world
applications. The project addresses anonymization on three fronts:

1) Textual data, even when explicit identifiers are removed (names,
dates, locations), can contain highly identifiable information. For
example, a sample of chief complaint fields from the Indiana Network
for Patient Care (INPC) found several instances of "phantom limb
pain". Amputees can be visually identifiable, but the HIPAA Safe
Harbor rules do not list this as "identifying information". Any
policy explicitly listing all types of identifying data is likely to
fail. Through a joint effort with computer science and linguistics,
the project is developing new methods to remove specific details from
text while preserving meaning, eliminating such highly identifiable
information without a priori knowledge of what would be identifying.

2) Current anonymization research is based on unproven measures of
identifiability. Through a re-identification challenge on synthetic
data (but based on real healthcare data), the project is evaluating
the efficacy of these measures. Interdisciplinary teams of students
are given challenge problems - anonymized data with hypothetical
healthcare data - and asked to make (hypothetical) inferences about
health information of individuals. The results can be used to
calibrate the effectiveness of different anonymization measures.

3) The utility of anonymized data has been a concern among research:
Does anonymized data provide credible research results? By partnering
with healthcare studies at the Kinsey Institute and Purdue University
School of Nursing, the project is comparing analyses on original data
with analyses on anonymized data, and evaluating the impact of types
of anonymization on research results. A related issue is determining
the impact on data collection: Are individuals more candid in their
responses if they know data will be anonymized? Outcomes are broadening
the scope of research that can be performed on anonymized data, while
ensuring that researchers know when access to individually identifiable
data (with attendant restrictions and safeguards) is needed.

Through these tasks, the project is advancing our ability to utilize
the wealth of data we now collect for the benefit of society, while
ensuring individual privacy is protected.

For further information see the project web site at the URL:
http://projects.cerias.purdue.edu/TextAnon

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are proud to report the successful completion of the project and fulfillment of its initial and additional intellectual merits and broader impacts.

Outcomes

• Achieved: Original Intellectual merit: Textual data, even when explicit identifiers are removed (names, dates, locations), can contain highly identifiable information. For example, a sample of chief complaint fields from the Indiana Network for Patient Care (INPC) found several instances of "phantom limb pain". Amputees can be visually identifiable, but the HIPAA Safe Harbor rules do not list this as "identifying information". Any policy explicitly listing all types of identifying data is likely to fail. Through a joint effort with computer science and linguistics, the project developed new methods to remove specific details from text while preserving meaning, eliminating such highly identifiable information without a priori knowledge of what would be identifying.

• Achieved: Original Broader Impacts: project is a step forward in advancing our ability to utilize the wealth of data we now collect for the benefit of society, while ensuring individual privacy is protected.

• Achieved: The ahead-of-the-curve understanding of enhanced anonymity. One main result is an advanced and innovative understanding of the true cognitive nature of anonymity, well beyond the usual name-address-SSN view of it and of the nature of effort to prevent reidentification.

Challenges

• The project was completed successfully in spite of two complications during its tenure. First, it was supposed to be applied to the Kinsey Reports but those have never been released to the researcher in spite of the persistent promises that have caused two no-cost extensions. This did not subvert the research: where a corpus was necessary it was replaced by a large real-life corpus of admission reports in emergency care, and the medical-support unit developed its efforts for any corpus.

• Second, the two first Principal Investigators have had to be replaced for logistical reasons: the first one went to rotate to the NSF for a few years, and the second left Purdue and academia for industry. Before departures, they had achieved valuable results and published their research in important outlets.

Further Outcomes

• Success in Semanticalization/Ontologization. As a result of overcoming the second challenge, the balance of the research moved to semantic, meaning-based computational methods for understanding of anonymity. Spelling mistakes or syntactic variations that could lead to identification of person who typed the notes, leading to identification of a location of where a patient was treated were taken into account. Serendipitously, this has been the increasing tendency in the community as well, and the project has taken a prominent role in this process.

• Success in Adapting and Improving Ontological Semantic Technology. Our meaning-based computational approach is based on the enhanced Ontological Semantic Technology initially funded by NSA and modified with NSF funding to CERIAS/Purdue. The main resource in the approach is an engineering comprehensive and language-independent ontology, which is a lattice of objects and events, linked by multiple properties linking them together. The language-dependent lexicons have all the senses of the words and phrasals anchored in the appropriate ontological concepts. A special software interprets every sentence in conceptual terms.

• Success in Implementing the General and Medical Resource for Handling Enhanced Anonymity. For this project, the language was English, and we have implemented ontology and lexicon for general and medical concepts. This allows us to collect all the properties assigned to a patient and identifies their unique combinations that would easily lead to re-identification. The solution is then to drop or to generalize enough properties to avoid the breach of anonymity.

• Graduate students from nursing, computer science, and statistics department identified digital data relevant to diabetes quality of care, evaluated the impact of anonymization on practical utility of data, and examined the relationships between the use of electronic personal health record and diabetes clinical outcomes.

• Guided a nursing student to conduct an integrative review regarding the effects of e-personal health records on diabetes clinical outcomes, including 10 RCT studies.  The student presented a poster in the Midwest Nursing Research Society conference in 2015 and earned a second place award.  This review showed that interventions requiring digital interactions (e.g., messaging) and data upload (e.g., blood sugar levels, symptoms) had positive effects on glycemic control; but few studies showed significant effects on blood pressure and lipid control.

• Collaborated with two PhD students (computer science and statistics) and conducted a retrospective study (July 2011 to June 2014, n = 1,244) to examine the relationships between the use of MyChart, demographics, and diabetes clinical outcomes.  Data before and after using MyChart were used.  Results showed significant relationship between MyChart usage and glycemic control among patients with poor glycemic control (HbA1c >9) at baseline and significant relationship between MyChart usage and lipid control among patients with high lipid level (LDL >100) before using MyChart. 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2016
Modified by: Victor Raskin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We are proud to report the successful completion of the project and fulfillment of its initial and additional intellectual merits and broader impacts. Outcomes • Achieved: Original Intellectual merit: Textual data, even when explicit identifiers are removed (names, dates, locations), can contain highly identifiable information. For example, a sample of chief complaint fields from the Indiana Network for Patient Care (INPC) found several instances of "phantom limb pain". Amputees can be visually identifiable, but the HIPAA Safe Harbor rules do not list this as "identifying information". Any policy explicitly listing all types of identifying data is likely to fail. Through a joint effort with computer science and linguistics, the project developed new methods to remove specific details from text while preserving meaning, eliminating such highly identifiable information without a priori knowledge of what would be identifying. • Achieved: Original Broader Impacts: project is a step forward in advancing our ability to utilize the wealth of data we now collect for the benefit of society, while ensuring individual privacy is protected. • Achieved: The ahead-of-the-curve understanding of enhanced anonymity. One main result is an advanced and innovative understanding of the true cognitive nature of anonymity, well beyond the usual name-address-SSN view of it and of the nature of effort to prevent reidentification. Challenges • The project was completed successfully in spite of two complications during its tenure. First, it was supposed to be applied to the Kinsey Reports but those have never been released to the researcher in spite of the persistent promises that have caused two no-cost extensions. This did not subvert the research: where a corpus was necessary it was replaced by a large real-life corpus of admission reports in emergency care, and the medical-support unit developed its efforts for any corpus. • Second, the two first Principal Investigators have had to be replaced for logistical reasons: the first one went to rotate to the NSF for a few years, and the second left Purdue and academia for industry. Before departures, they had achieved valuable results and published their research in important outlets. Further Outcomes • Success in Semanticalization/Ontologization. As a result of overcoming the second challenge, the balance of the research moved to semantic, meaning-based computational methods for understanding of anonymity. Spelling mistakes or syntactic variations that could lead to identification of person who typed the notes, leading to identification of a location of where a patient was treated were taken into account. Serendipitously, this has been the increasing tendency in the community as well, and the project has taken a prominent role in this process. • Success in Adapting and Improving Ontological Semantic Technology. Our meaning-based computational approach is based on the enhanced Ontological Semantic Technology initially funded by NSA and modified with NSF funding to CERIAS/Purdue. The main resource in the approach is an engineering comprehensive and language-independent ontology, which is a lattice of objects and events, linked by multiple properties linking them together. A special software interprets every sentence in conceptual terms. • Success in Implementing the General and Medical Resource for Handling Enhanced Anonymity. For this project, the language was English, and we have implemented ontology and lexicon for general and medical concepts. This allows us to collect all the properties assigned to a patient and identifies their unique combinations that would easily lead to re-identification. The solution is then to drop or to generalize enough properties to avoid the breach of anonymity. • Graduate students from nursing, computer science, and statistics department identified digital data relevant to diabetes quality of care, evaluated the impact of anonymization on practical utility of data, and examined the relationships between the use of electronic personal health record and diabetes clinical outcomes. • Guided a nursing student to conduct an integrative review regarding the effects of e-personal health records on diabetes clinical outcomes, including 10 RCT studies. The student presented a poster in the Midwest Nursing Research Society conference in 2015 and earned a second place award. This review showed that interventions requiring digital interactions (e.g., messaging) and data upload (e.g., blood sugar levels, symptoms) had positive effects on glycemic control; but few studies showed significant effects on blood pressure and lipid control. • Collaborated with two PhD students (computer science and statistics) and conducted a retrospective study (July 2011 to June 2014, n = 1,244) to examine the relationships between the use of MyChart, demographics, and diabetes clinical outcomes. Data before and after using MyChart were used. Results showed significant relationship between MyChart usage and glycemic control among patients with poor glycemic control (HbA1c >9) at baseline and significant relationship between MyChart usage and lipid control among patients with high lipid level (LDL >100) before using MyChart.
